training_examples.customer_question: What's the difference between a hard bounce and a soft bounce?

ideal_response.simple_explanation:
Great question! Understanding bounce types is key to maintaining good deliverability.

**HARD BOUNCES (5.x.x error codes)**
- Permanent failures - these emails will never be delivered
- The email address doesn't exist or is invalid
- ‚úì Action: Remove from your list IMMEDIATELY
- ‚úì Target: < 2% of your sends

**SOFT BOUNCES (4.x.x error codes)**  
- Temporary failures - might work if you retry later
- Mailbox full, server temporarily down, message too large
- ‚úì Action: Automatic retry, but remove after 3-5 failed attempts
- ‚úì Target: < 5% of your sends

hard_bounce_codes.5.1.1: Email address doesn't exist - Remove immediately

soft_bounce_codes.4.2.2: Mailbox full - Retry later, remove if persists
soft_bounce_codes.4.4.1: Server connection issue - Temporary, will retry
soft_bounce_codes.4.7.1: Greylisting (spam protection) - Normal, will succeed on retry

reputation_impacting_codes.5.7.1: Spam block - Impacts reputation, investigate immediately
reputation_impacting_codes.5.7.606: Microsoft suspicious activity - Reduce volume ASAP

best_practices: Monitor daily bounce rates by ESP
Set up automatic hard bounce suppression
Soft bounce: Retry 3-5 times over 72 hours, then suppress
Alert if bounce rate >5% on any campaign

- Hard bounces: Should be <2%

training_examples.customer_question: How do I set up SPF, DKIM, and DMARC? I'm confused about what records to add.

ideal_response.overview: Great question! Email authentication is critical for deliverability. I'll walk you through each record and provide exactly what you need to add.
ideal_response.why_authentication_matters:
Without proper authentication:
‚ùå Microsoft/Gmail will filter to spam
‚ùå Higher bounce rates
‚ùå Phishing protection may block you
‚ùå DMARC reports show failures

With proper authentication:
‚úì Better inbox placement
‚úì Lower spam rates
‚úì Brand protection
‚úì Required by most ESPs

step_1_spf.what_it_is: SPF (Sender Policy Framework) lists which mail servers are allowed to send email for your domain.

breakdown.include:_spf.blueshift.com: Authorizes Blueshift to send for your domain
breakdown.~all: Soft fail for others (use -all for hard fail after testing)

step_1_spf.your_exact_record:
For Blueshift customers:

Host: @ (or leave blank, or example.com)
Type: TXT
Value: v=spf1 include:_spf.blueshift.com ~all
TTL: 3600 (or default)

Note: If you have existing SPF, ADD include:_spf.blueshift.com before the ~all
step_1_spf.testing:
Verify after 1-24 hours:
- Use MXToolbox.com SPF checker
- Send test email to mail-tester.com
- Check passes 10/10

step_2_dkim.what_it_is: DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail) adds a digital signature to your emails proving they're authentic.
step_2_dkim.blueshift_process:
1. Blueshift generates unique DKIM keys for you
2. We provide 2-3 CNAME records to add
3. You add them to your DNS
4. We verify and enable
step_2_dkim.example_records:
You'll receive records like:

Host: bshift1._domainkey.example.com
Type: CNAME
Value: bshift1.dkim.blueshift.com

Host: bshift2._domainkey.example.com  
Type: CNAME
Value: bshift2.dkim.blueshift.com
step_2_dkim.your_action: I can generate your specific DKIM records now. What's your sending domain?
common_mistakes: ‚ùå Typo in the subdomain (_domainkey is common mistake)
‚ùå Using TXT instead of CNAME (when CNAME provided)
‚ùå Not waiting for DNS propagation (24-48 hours)
step_2_dkim.testing:
Verify after 24-48 hours:
- Use MXToolbox.com DKIM checker
- Selector name provided by Blueshift
- Should show valid DKIM record

step_3_dmarc.what_it_is: DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication) tells receivers what to do if SPF/DKIM fail, and sends you reports.

breakdown.fo=1: Generate report if either SPF or DKIM fails

step_3_dmarc.your_exact_record:
Start with monitoring policy:

Host: _dmarc.example.com (or _dmarc)
Type: TXT
Value: v=DMARC1; p=none; rua=mailto:dmarc@yourdomain.com; pct=100; fo=1
TTL: 3600
step_3_dmarc.policy_progression:
**Phase 1 (Weeks 1-4): p=none**
- Monitor only, don't block anything
- Review reports weekly
- Fix any authentication issues

**Phase 2 (Weeks 5-8): p=quarantine**  
- Failed emails go to spam
- Still monitoring reports
- Ensure no legitimate mail fails

**Phase 3 (Week 9+): p=reject**
- Failed emails completely rejected
- Strongest protection
- Only after confirming no false positives
step_3_dmarc.reports_explained:
DMARC reports show:
- Who's sending email from your domain
- Whether emails pass/fail authentication
- Unauthorized senders (potential spoofing)
- Volume by sending source

Use free tools like dmarcian.com or Postmark to parse reports
common_mistakes: ‚ùå Using email address you don't monitor
step_3_dmarc.testing:
Verify after 24-48 hours:
- Use MXToolbox.com DMARC checker
- Should show valid record
- Start receiving daily reports

‚ñ° DKIM records requested from Blueshift

blacklist_removal.if_blacklisted:
Additional steps if you're on blacklists:

**Identify Blacklists:**
- Check MXToolbox.com/blacklists
- Common ones: Spamhaus, SURBL, Barracuda

**Removal Process:**
1. Fix root cause FIRST (or you'll get re-listed)
2. Wait 24-48 hours to demonstrate improvement
3. Request delisting through each blacklist's removal form
4. Provide evidence of corrective actions
5. Some are automatic (24-48 hours), some manual (1-2 weeks)

**Note:** Some blacklists require waiting period before removal

esp_specific_recovery.microsoft:
Hardest to recover with:
- Monitor SNDS daily
- May take 6-8 weeks for full recovery
- Start with very low volume (500-1,000/day)
- Focus on engagement over volume
esp_specific_recovery.gmail:
Moderate recovery time:
- Google Postmaster shows progress
- Engagement-focused (opens/replies)
- Can see improvement in 3-4 weeks
- A/B test subject lines aggressively
esp_specific_recovery.yahoo:
Variable recovery:
- No public tools to monitor
- Watch deferral rates
- Very sensitive to spam complaints
- Recovery in 4-6 weeks typical

ideal_response.realistic_expectations:
**Week 1-2:** Metrics stabilize, stop getting worse

**Week 9-12:** Full recovery achieved

ideal_response.when_to_consider_fresh_start:
In some extreme cases, starting fresh is better:

**Consider new IP/domain if:**
- Multiple critical blacklists (Spamhaus DROP/EDROP)
- Complete blocks across all major ESPs
- Purchased list used extensively
- Reputation damaged beyond practical recovery
- Business urgency requires faster solution

But remember: New IP requires full warmup (6-8 weeks) and root causes must be fixed first.
